Research Paper Significant enhanced SO2 resistance of Ce-doped OMS-2 catalyst by building the CeO2 shell for the low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3 Xiaomin Wu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft a ⁎ Chao Yu Writing – original draft a Geyu Dai Supervision a Yuewang Peng Supervision a Zhiwei Huang Supervision Funding acquisition a Huawang Zhao Supervision a Guohua Jing Funding acquisition a Wei Li Supervision b a Department of Environmental Science & Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen, Fujian 361021, PR China Department of Environmental Science & Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Huaqiao University Xiamen Fujian 361021 PR China aDepartment of Environmental Science & Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen, Fujian 361021, PR China b Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Institute of Industrial Ecology and Environment, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education Institute of Industrial Ecology and Environment College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China bKey Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Institute of Industrial Ecology and Environment, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Developing highly SO2-resistance catalysts for the NOx reduction at low temperatures is a significant challenge. In this study, we fabricate a catalyst of Ce-doped manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieve by building the CeO2 shell (Ce-OMS-2@CeO2) to solve this problem. This catalyst showed high selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) activity and enhanced resistance to SO2-induced deactivation. Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 exhibited outstanding NH3-SCR activity and anti-sulfur performance at 200 °C. The mesoporous CeO2 shells exerted no influence on the transport of reactants to catalytic active sites. The NH3-SCR on Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst occurred via the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with adsorption of NH3 and NO on different sites, thus preventing competing adsorption. The CeO2 shell bound SO2 strongly in priority, thus protecting the Ce-OMS-2 core from SO2 poisoning. Moreover, a dynamic balance was established between NH4HSO4 formation and decomposition over our Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst at low temperatures, which also hindered the SO2 poisoning in NH3-SCR reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CeO2 Ce-OMS-2 Core-shell structure NH3-SCR SO2 resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) at low temperature is regarded as one of the most promising post-combustion control technologies for nitrogen oxides (NOx) emission control, especially in the removal of NOx from power plants and other stationary sources [1]. Although the commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst is widely used in stationary applications, there is still some disadvantages, such as poor activity at low temperatures, biological toxicity and a narrow temperature window (300–400 °C) [2]. Therefore, Mn-based catalysts have been developed for NH3-SCR at low temperatures due to a multi-valence of MnOx and remarkable redox properties [3–5]. Recently, a manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieve (K-OMS-2) with a special 2 × 2 tunnel showed the best low-temperature NH3-SCR activity among the Mn-based catalysts [6–8]. Moreover, our investigations revealed that the introduction of Ce into the framework and tunnel of K-OMS-2 enhanced NO conversion at low temperatures. The main reason was that they can maintain the structure of octahedral molecular sieves in in high oxidation states (Mn4+/Mn3+) and keep the charge transfer of Mn and Ce ascribing to Ce-O-Mn bond [9]. However, an inevitable problem of Ce-doped K-OMS-2 is that the deactivation of catalysts in the presence of sulfur dioxide (SO2) in the NH3-SCR reaction. Hence, great effort should be made to enhance the SO2 tolerance of the Ce-doped K-OMS-2 catalyst. The deactivation of the Ce-doped K-OMS-2 catalyst is ascribed to the direct reaction of SO2 with Mn active sites to form manganese sulfates, leading to the collapse of the octahedral molecular sieve of K-OMS-2. Thus, how to maintain the structure of octahedral molecular sieves in the presence of SO2 is an important research topic. To date, cerium oxide (CeO2) has been widely utilized in various fields of industrial and environmental applications ascribing to its high oxygen storage capacity and redox ability [10]. The introduction of CeO2 is strong anti-SO2 performance in NH3-SCR process. For instance, SO2 exhibited an affinity for Ce, thereby preventing the sulfation of center Mn [11]. Furthermore, we developed CeO2-promoted V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst which accelerated ammonium bisulfate (NH4HSO4, ABS) decomposition for improved SO2 resistance [12]. Therefore, if we tailor the catalyst's structure to preferentially expose CeO2, SO2 will primarily react with CeO2 to protect the active sites of Ce-doped K-OMS-2 from SO2 poisoning. In recent years, core-shell catalysts, comprised of inner cores and outer shells, have become a hotspot, which generally possessed high specific surface areas, good mass transfer of reactants and products [13]. Given the superiority of both core-shell and CeO2 structure, the construction of a CeO2 shell structure seems a wise choice to maintain the catalytic performance. What's more, the core-shell structure is expected to enhance the SO2 resistance attributed to the presence of the mesoporous CeO2 shells [14]. In addition, it also reported that a mesoporous shell will be favorable for the decomposition of ABS and some sulfate species [15]. Therefore, SO2 contact with the designed CeO2 shell firstly, which refrains from SO2 deactivation caused by the direct binding to the Mn active sites of Ce-doped K-OMS-2. In this work, we synthesized Ce-doped K-OMS-2 (Ce-OMS-2) and core-shell Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalysts. The NH3-SCR efficiency of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst exhibited excellent low-temperature catalytic activity and SO2 tolerance, which is significantly superior to the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst. Characterization revealed that the effects of CeO2 shell to enhance SO2 tolerance and the influence mechanism of CeO2 shell on NH3-SCR. The mesoporous CeO2 shell firstly bound SO2, protecting the Ce-OMS-2 core from SO2 poisoning. Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 showed higher SO2 resistance than Ce-OMS-2 due to a noncompetitive Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism and more accessible active sites. Finally, a dynamic balance was established between ABS formation and decomposition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The Ce-doped K-OMS-2 catalyst was prepared by a hydrothermal method as reported previously [9], and is denoted as Ce-OMS-2. The coating of the CeO2 shell on the Ce-OMS-2 surface was also synthesized via a hydrothermal method [16], labeled as Ce-OMS-2@CeO2. In situ poisoning of samples was carried out over a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor for 4 h at 200 °C. The total flow rate of raw gas was 600 mL/min with the inlet gas comprising 600 ppm of NH3, 600 ppm of NO, 200 ppm of SO2, 10 vol.% H2O, 5 vol.% O2, and N2 as the balance gas. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were performed on a Bruker X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation operating at 40 kV and 30 mA with 10° and 90°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using Al Kα radiation, and the binding energy of C1 s = 284.80 eV was used as the energy standard to compensate for the surface charge effect. The specific areas were measured by a Micromeritics nitrogen adsorption apparatus using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted with a TCD equipment to monitor NH3. Before the experiment, the sample (0.1 g, 40–60 mesh) was discharged with helium at 300 °C for 30 min. After cooling to ambient temperature, NH3 was introduced to adsorb to saturation at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. Then, the baseline was levelled with He, and the temperature was programmed to 800 °C at a constant gradient temperature of 10 °C/min. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a Micromeritics chemisorption apparatus. 5 vol.% H2/Ar was introduced to the sample (0.1 g, 40–60 mesh) at a flow rate of 50 mL/min for 30 min. The temperature was programmed to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Thermogravimetry analysis (TG) was performed on a thermo-analyzer with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with NO was performed using the ABS-loaded catalysts at constant gradient temperature of 5 °C/min. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted on a FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50) equipped with a high-temperature reaction cell. All in situ DRIFTS spectra were collected by accumulating 64 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The sample (∼50 mg) was pretreated in N2 at 200 °C for 30 min before each experiment. The background spectra were collected under a flow of N2 before each experiment. The compositions of the reactant gases were as follows: N2 + O2 (5 vol.%) + NH3 (600 ppm) + NO2 (600 ppm) at a flow rate of 100 mL/min. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The performance of the catalyst was conducted over a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor (i.d.= 6 mm). The catalyst (0.2 g, 40–60 mesh) was packed in the middle of the flow reactor. The reaction temperature was regulated from 30 to 400 °C at constant gradient temperature of 5 °C/min. The component of reactant mixture of 600 ppm NO, 600 ppm NH3, 5 vol.% O2, 10 vol.% H2O, 200 ppm SO2 with N2 as balance under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 170,000 h−1. The concentrations of NO in the outlet of the flow reactor were determined by Testo 350. The N2 selectivity was detected by using a FTIR spectrometer instead of the Testo 350, and the calculation was carried out according to the following formula: N O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n ) × 100 % N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activities and SO2 resistance The NH3-SCR performance versus the reaction temperature for Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalysts was evaluated. As can be seen from Fig. 1a , both Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 displayed superior catalytic activity in the temperature region of 100∼220 °C, which can be attributable to the influence of activate Ce-OMS-2 in the core. However, the decreased N2 selectivity for the Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalysts was due to the strong oxidation ability of Mn at high temperature, leading to the transition oxidation of NH3 to N2O (Fig. 1(b, c)) [17,18]. In addition, pure CeO2 showed unfavorable NO conversion, suggesting that Ce-OMS-2 was the active site for NH3-SCR performance. The NO conversion in the presence of SO2 and H2O at 200 °C was tested to evaluate the SO2 tolerance. Compared with the decrease in performance of Ce-OMS-2 (decline to 16 % after 4 h), Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 showed substantially enhanced anti-sulfur performance at 200 °C. In conclusion, it revealed that Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 exhibited outstanding NH3-SCR activity and anti-sulfur performance, making it great potential for future utilizations in NOx elimination from stationary sources. 3.2 Structure of the catalysts XRD, BET and electron microscopic techniques to disclose the morphology and structure of Ce-OMS-2 before and after coating with CeO2 layers. The XRD patterns of the as-prepared Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 samples are depicted Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2a, for Ce-OMS-2, a broad characteristic diffraction patterns for KMn8O16 (PDF#20-0908) was observed due to the Ce incorporation of K-OMS-2. For Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, it was clear that the characteristic of cubic CeO2 (PDF#02-1306) and KMn8O16 (PDF#20-0908) were presented after the construction of a CeO2 shell, which could be due to the coating of CeO2 shell. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and porous properties were carried out to investigate the change of the textural properties before and after coverage of CeO2 layers, and the results are shown in Fig. 2b and Table 1 . The Ce-OMS-2 exhibited a type IV hysteresis loop, revealing the mesoporous structures. The Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 sample exhibited the typical IV isotherms with the H3-type hysteresis loops, which was consistent with that of Ce-OMS-2. This result revealed that a mesoporous structure could be maintained over the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 material. As displayed in Table 1, the specific surface area of Ce-OMS-2 was 114.6 m2/g. Obviously, Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 possessed similar specific surface area (118.4 m2/g) to Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, which could due to the maintained mesoporous structure even coating of a CeO2 shell. In addition, the decrease rate of the BET surface area of poisoned Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 (∼25 %) was less than that of poisoned Ce-OMS-2 (∼55 %) (Table 1). It was attributed to the strong binding of SO2 by the CeO2 shell, thus protecting the Ce-OMS-2 core from SO2 poisoning. The partial accumulation of ABS on the outer CeO2 shell will not affect the transport of gaseous NO and NH3, in accordance with the result of NH3-SCR. The pore sizes of Ce-OMS-2 sample (11.23 nm) is larger than that of core-shell Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 (6.84 nm). The decreased pore size is related to the partial coverage of the porous structure and partial blockage of Ce-OMS-2 by CeO2. To further analyze the CeO2 shell, the morphology of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 was examined using TEM and HRTEM. As illustrated in Fig. 3a , the TEM image revealed that the as-prepared Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 consisted of a large number of rough-faced nanoparticles. Further HR-TEM image in Fig. 3b clearly demonstrated that the lattice spacing of the small nanoparticles is 0.27 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the characteristic (200) and (111) planes of fluorite-type CeO2. As exhibited in Fig. 3c, the outer surface of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 was successfully covered by a thin CeO2 “layer”, indicating the successful formation of the shell layer CeO2 surface. Furthermore, the TEM line scanning analyses of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 combined with EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 3(d-f)), clearly reveals the core-shell structure of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2. The element Ce was homogeneously dispersed in the outer shell while the Mn phase mainly existed in the core. Therefore, as expected, the core-shell structure of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 has been successfully synthesized. To better clarify the core-shell structure, an EDS mapping analysis obviously displayed the presence of O, Mn, Ce elements. As shown in Fig. 3(e, f), the element Ce was homogeneously dispersed in the outer shell while the Mn phase mainly existed in the core. The result is in accordance with the HR-TEM profiles. This demonstrated that the core-shell Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 material was successfully synthesized. 3.3 Redox properties and surface acidity The redox behavior and surface acidity was essential for the understanding of the NH3-SCR reaction. Therefore, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were conducted to study the changes in reducibility and acidity of the catalysts before and after coating by CeO2 shell, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4a , for Ce-OMS-2, the bands at 200 and 288 °C were assigned to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and further reduction of Mn2O3 to MnO at higher temperature [7]. Notably, for Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, compared with Ce-OMS-2 catalyst, the reduction peak of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and the subsequent reduction of Mn2O3 to MnO shifted to high temperature, suggesting that a stronger charge transfer existed in the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 material. It was obviously observed that the H2 consumption of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 increased due to the addition of CeO2 as shell structure. According previous literatures [19,20], CeO2 shell weakened the reduction ability and increased the acidity due to the shielding effect of shell structure, which is clarified in NH3-TPD. Fig. 4b depicts the NH3 desorption profile of Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, respectively. The peaks at 100–300 (I), 300–400 (II), and 400–550 °C (III) were related to weak acid sites, medium acid sites, and strong acid sites, respectively [21]. Notably, for Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, compared with Ce-OMS-2 catalyst, the number of weak acid sites decreased, while that of strong acid sites increased significantly. According to previous literatures, the coordinated NH3 species adsorbed at the Lewis acid site had more thermal stability than the NH4 + species adsorbed at the Brønsted acid site [22]. Therefore, a large number of strong Lewis acid sites and a few Bronsted acid sites were located on the surface of the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst due to the shielding effect of CeO2 shell structure. It demonstrated that the coating of a CeO2 shell could significantly enhance the acidity, inhibiting gaseous SO2 adsorption and thereby improving SO2 resistance. 3.4 Surface active species and sulfur poisoning resistance TG-DTG analysis of the Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 samples were performed to investigate the generation of the surface species after in situ SO2-poisoning. As shown in Fig. 5 , four typical weight loss steps presented over the samples after in situ SO2-poisoning. Firstly, the initial weight loss occurred at the temperature less than 200 °C ascribing to the release of physically adsorbed H2O and the decomposition of partial NH4HSO4 (ABS) [23]. Secondly, the weight loss appeared between 200 and 500 °C, which was attributed to the release of NH3 from the thermal decomposition of ABS [24]. Then, as the temperature increased, the third peak of weight loss from 500 to 700 °C due to the occurrence of a phase transition from Ce-OMS-2 to Mn2O3 and CeO2 [25]. Finally, the last weight loss of occurred above 700 °C corresponding to the decomposition of metal sulfate and releasing SO2 [23]. It was obviously that the curves of TG-DTG were quite different for Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, respectively. For the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 sample, the intensity of deposited ABS peak (ca. 1.84 wt.%) in the curve was weaker than that over the Ce-OMS-2 (ca. 3.26 wt.%) sample, indicating that the shell CeO2 hindered the decomposition of ABS on the surface of the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst. On the contrary, more ABS was formed on the Ce-OMS-2 surface after in situ SO2-poisoning, resulting the stronger intensity of deposited ABS peak. Furthermore, the amount of metal sulfate species over the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst (ca. 1.68 wt.%) was weaker than that over the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst ((ca. 8.84 wt.%)). These results revealed that the Mn active sites of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 could be protected from SO2 poisoning due to the existence of the CeO2 shell. XPS analysis was conducted to characterize the chemical status of the sulfur species of the sulfurized Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalysts after in situ SO2-poisoning, as illustrated in Fig. 6a and Table 1. For Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst, the peak at ∼169.2 eV was assigned to the S6+ of SO4 2−, while the peak at ∼168.5 eV was attributed to the S4+ of SO3 2− [26]. Both SO3 2− and SO4 2− species were presented on the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst. What’ more, the XPS spectra of S 2p bands of Ce-OMS-2 shifted to a higher B.E. compared with that of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2. This ∼0.5 eV upshift indicated that SO3 2− on Ce-OMS-2 was prone to loss electrons to form SO4 2−, thus accelerating the generation of ABS. Table 1 suggested that the surface S content on the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst (2.2 wt.%) was lower than that on the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst (4.8 wt.%). less sulfur species produced on the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst compared with the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst, in accordance with the lower weight loss of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 in the TG-DTG result. These changes revealed that the CeO2 shell could protect active Ce-OMS-2 from being sulfated, eventually maintaining ∼80 % NO conversion in the presence of SO2 and H2O. TPSR with NO were performed to compare the reactivity of deposited ABS on the 10 wt.% ABS-loaded Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 samples. As presented in Fig. 6b, The TPSR of the 10 wt.% ABS/Ce-OMS-2 reveals that a single and broad TPSR peak centered at 290 °C occurred. For 10 wt.% ABS/Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 samples, the TPSR peak of NO concentration shifted to lower temperature by ∼ 60 °C than that for 10 wt.% ABS/Ce-OMS-2, suggesting an extremely rapid decomposition and reactivity of deposited ABS over ABS/Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 [27]. This result suggested that a dynamic balance between ABS formation and decomposition occurred over the ABS/Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst even at low temperature (220 °C), which hindered the SO2 poisoning in NH3-SCR reaction [28]. 3.5 Kinetic investigation The pressure dependence studies on NH3-SCR reaction were performed to investigate the reaction mechanisms of different active sites and to establish reaction models. The experiments were conducted by varying the space velocity to calculate the reaction rates under differential reaction conditions, with NO conversion typically below 15 %. Fig. 7 illustrates the normalized NO conversion rate as a function of the partial pressures of reactants (NH3 and NO). NO conversion rates on the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst (Fig. 7(a, b)) show a first-order (gradient 1.00) dependence on [NH3] (measured at a constant 300 ppm NO) and a first-order (gradient 1.22) and negative first-order (gradient −0.78) dependence on [NO], respectively (measured at a constant 600 ppm NH3). The first-order dependence on the partial pressure of NH3 and NO within low NO pressure regimes (< 0.3 kPa) suggests that active sites are not saturated with a combination of NH3 and NO intermediates, while reaction rates show decreased inverse first-order dependence (−0.78) with the increasing NO pressure. It leads to the competing adsorption of NH3, which indicates that NH3 and NO co-adsorbed at the same site over Ce-OMS-2 undergo the Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction mechanism [29]. In the case of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2, as shown in Fig. 7(c, d), the NO conversion rates exhibited a first-order (gradient 0.98) and zero-order (−0.15) dependence on [NH3] (measured at a constant 300 ppm NO), as well as a first-order (gradient 1.13) dependence on [NO] (measured at a constant 300 ppm NH3). The results suggest that the NH3-SCR mechanism over the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst is distinct from that of the Ce-OMS-2 model catalyst. This difference is indicated by the zero-order dependence on the NH3 partial pressure, which suggests the absence of competitive adsorption between NH3 and NO on Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 [30]. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, which involves non-competitive adsorption of NH3 and NO molecules on two different types of sites, is the most plausible model for describing the NH3-SCR behavior over Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst. We can summarize the active sites involved in NH3-SCR over the Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 are different, even undergo the Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction mechanism. The NH3-SCR on Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst occurs via the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with adsorption on different sites, preventing competing adsorption. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS To clarify the effect of CeO2 core shell on the classifications and quantities of adsorbed NOx species, the in situ DRIFTS spectra of NO+O2 adsorption over Ce-OMS-2 and Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalysts are presented. As shown in Fig. 8a , for Ce-OMS-2, two distinct bands at 1450 and 1369 cm−1 can be ascribed to nitro species [31]. And the peak observed at 1309 cm−1 was assigned to monodentate nitrate [32]. Note that after the coverage of CeO2 layers, as shown in Fig. 8c, new bands belonging to the bidentate nitrate (1562 cm−1) appeared [33]. And the intensity of all the bands over the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst was much higher than that over Ce-OMS-2 catalyst. This result indicates that the mesoporous CeO2 shell tremendously increased the adsorption capacity of reactant NO, which was advantageous for improving the catalytic NH3-SCR activity. Moreover, it is noted that the bidentate nitrate was an important intermediate due to its reaction with gaseous NH3 to produce H2NNO and then decomposed to N2 and H2O [34], which was conducive to the reduction of NOx. In summary, the facile diffusion of gaseous NO in the core-shell structure of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst could significantly improve the NO conversion efficiency. 3.7 Influence mechanism of CeO2 shell on NH3-SCR The above results were analyzed to reveal the mechanism over Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 for the removal of NO in the presence of SO2, as shown in Scheme 1 . In the presence of SO2, the Ce-OMS-2 catalyst can easily react with SO2 to generate a number of manganese sulfate (MnSO4) at low temperature (200 °C) after 100 min, resulting in a decrease of the NO conversion. It was due to collapse of the KMn8O16 structure of the Ce-OMS-2 material [9]. Therefore, we established a core-shell structure that promoted the adsorption of NO and NH3. Simultaneously, the core-shell structure can prohibit the Mn active sites from being SO2-poisoning on the surface of the catalyst. Our designed Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst exhibited promoted SO2 resistance at 200 °C ascribing to the self-prevention effect of the CeO2 shell layer. Firstly, constructing the CeO2 shell layer on the Ce-OMS-2 surface preserved the mesoporous structures, allowing the reactants transmission. SO2 reacted with the CeO2 shell layer directly to form cerium sulfate in priority to the poisoning of Ce-OMS-2. Because the molecular diameter of NO was smaller than that of SO2, NO can penetrate the CeO2 shell surface and react with NH3 on the Mn active sites of the Ce-OMS-2 core. Thus, it weakened the influence of SO2, which is beneficial for the removal of NO in the presence of SO2. On the other hand, Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 enhanced the decomposition of ABS. A dynamic balance of ABS formation and decomposition was achieved over Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 even at low temperatures, which hindered the SO2 poisoning during the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, this coating of a CeO2 shell significantly enhanced the acidity and provided an appropriate reduction ability for NH3/NO adsorption and hindered SO2 adsorption. Generally, this self-prevention effect of Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 preserved the reactivity of gaseous NO and NH3, resulting in outstanding NO conversion and good SO2 resistance at low temperatures. 4 Conclusion In this work, a highly SO2-resistancee core-shell structured Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst was developed for the catalytic NO conversion. Our Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst exhibited outstanding NH3-SCR activities and SO2 resistance for 4 h at 200 °C. We attributed to CeO2 shell could protect active Ce-OMS-2 from being sulfated, eventually maintaining ∼80 % NO conversion even exposed to SO2 and H2O. From the BET, XRD and TEM results, the mesoporous CeO2 shell did not affect the transport of reactant to catalytic active sites. The core-shell structure could significantly enhance the acidity and provide an appropriate reduction ability, thereby contributing to the high-efficiency NO conversion at low-temperatures. Furthermore, CeO2 shell reacted with SO2 strongly in priority to the poisoning of Ce-OMS-2 core, effectively impeding the formation of MnSO4. A dynamic balance between ABS formation and decomposition occurred over the Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst, prohibiting the SO2 poisoning during the NH3-SCR process. coredata.dc:description: Developing highly SO2-resistance catalysts for the NOx reduction at low temperatures is a significant challenge. In this study, we fabricate a catalyst of Ce-doped manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieve by building the CeO2 shell (Ce-OMS-2@CeO2) to solve this problem. This catalyst showed high selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) activity and enhanced resistance to SO2-induced deactivation. Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 exhibited outstanding NH3-SCR activity and anti-sulfur performance at 200 °C. The mesoporous CeO2 shells exerted no influence on the transport of reactants to catalytic active sites. The NH3-SCR on Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst occurred via the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with adsorption of NH3 and NO on different sites, thus preventing competing adsorption. The CeO2 shell bound SO2 strongly in priority, thus protecting the Ce-OMS-2 core from SO2 poisoning. Moreover, a dynamic balance was established between NH4HSO4 formation and decomposition over our Ce-OMS-2@CeO2 catalyst at low temperatures, which also hindered the SO2 poisoning in NH3-SCR reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Significant enhanced SO2 resistance of Ce-doped OMS-2 catalyst by building the CeO2 shell for the low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3
